translated: Hall, Agnar August, hospital physician, Norrköping, born April 10th, 1899 in Alvesta, Kronoberg County, son of savings bank director Daniel August H. and Gunhild Fältström. Married on May 30th with Arla Dagmar Teuchler. Children: Eva born in 1932, Ulla in 1934, Lars and Björn in 1936, Klas in 1940. Completed high school in Lund in 1919, earned a Bachelor's degree in medicine from Karolinska Institute in 1924 and a medical degree there in 1928. Studied abroad in Denmark, Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Austria, France, the Netherlands in 1930 and 1937, in the United States in 1945, and in England in 1946. Served as an assistant doctor between 1926-1929, as a temporary assistant at Serafina Hospital's ear clinic for four months in 1929-1930, as a doctor at Helsingborg Hospital's X-ray department in 1930, as a temporary junior doctor at Sahlgranska Hospital's ear department for six months in 1931-1932, as a second temporary medical officer at Uddevalla Hospital's surgical department in 1931-1933, including as acting first temporary doctor for eight months, as an assistant doctor at Serafina Hospital's ear clinic in 1933-1934, as a substitute doctor for eight months and as a temporary doctor in Karlstad and as a temporary medical officer at Sahlgranska Hospital for four months in 1934-1936, as a temporary doctor at Sabbatsberg Hospital's ear clinic in 1936-1937, as a physician at Norrköping Hospital's ear, nose, and throat department in 1937-1938, and as a hospital physician there since 1939. He was chairman of the Norrköping chapter of the Swedish Red Cross and of the local branch of the Swedish Association for the Deaf. He wrote several papers in professional journals.

structured.name: Agnar August Hall
jobTitle: Physician at ear, nose, and throat department
structured.description: Agnar August Hall was a Swedish hospital physician and expert in ear, nose, and throat diseases. He was born on April 10th, 1899 in Alvesta, Kronoberg County, and earned a Bachelor's degree in medicine from Karolinska Institute in 1924 and a medical degree there in 1928. He studied abroad in several countries, including the United States, and served in various assistant and temporary doctor positions before becoming a physician at Norrköping Hospital in 1939. He was also the chairman of the Norrköping chapter of the Swedish Red Cross and of the local branch of the Swedish Association for the Deaf. Throughout his career, he wrote several papers in professional journals.
